list.Title: Harbourwalk
list.description: What happens when you look at something familiar for a longer period and from a different perspective? The port in Basel has been my workplace since 2019; every day I see the structures, warehouses, cranes, and ships. Industry has scaled back, but it still exists, and it has the feel of a somewhat vibrant ghost town.
list.content_01_text: Sometimes you see something every day, but if you take the time to look more closely, it looks completely different. And by sometimes, I actually mean almost every time. The superdot office is located in Basel's Rhine harbor, and even though I cycle between the harbor basins practically every day, you still notice new structures when you look more closely.
list.content_05_text: This photo series was my first trial run with the Sony A6100, which I now keep as a staple in my fanny pack. I'm amazed at how APS-C cameras now allow for such compact, portable quality.

gear.description: I've always dabbled in photography, whether as a theater photographer, as visual diary, or as a helpful tool to capture the people around me just as I see them. This camera was a gift and means a great deal to me. It has rekindled my interest in scene composition and imagery.

list.Title: Mission Iris
list.description: Two women, two gods, and one all-seeing eye. Mission Iris 3052 is my ongoing graphic novel project, a visual sci-fi rock opera for all who love humanity and want to journey along the current of history.

Teaser-Image.path: download/noco/pv3c5ekh1fjoihu/mieh9d1y7a7ls74/c18fm6jyb2wfvqr/Sehetz Sarah Heitz skill Illustration mission Iris 01_nxC2y.webp

gear.description: Who wouldn't love having their favorite tool always at hand? I grew up with digital drawing, from my first Wacom Bamboo Fun tablet at age eleven to over two Wacom Cintiqs (12 UX, 24 pro) that I lugged across Europe in my hand luggage several times. The iPad? For me, a lifelong dream.

Teaser-Image.title: Sehetz Sarah Heitz Gear Ipad Crop.svg

list.Title: Chebby Chic
list.description: Snow-covered fairytale forests in the Czech Republic. In 2016, a friend and I got lost in the woods around Cheb, yielded the right of way to a fawn on the road, and startled ourselves with the crunching sound of a twig caught in the wheel spokes. These increasingly dark photographs came together during the day that the forest completely captivated us.
list.content_01_text: The longer we stayed, the more the forest seemed to close in. Winter muted the colors, shortened the distance, and absorbed sound. Darkness arrived early, and ordinary details began to feel charged. The road guided us forward while limiting what we could see, leaving space for imagination to take over.
list.content_03_text: The images emerged along the way, taken from the car without staging or interruption. Roads cut through the frames and set their rhythm. The series balances a sense of looming unease with its own ordinariness. Nothing reveals itself, nothing escalates.

team.description: Trier University of Applied Sciences isn't the best university in the world, in Germany, or perhaps even in Rhineland-Palatinate. Nevertheless, I wouldn't trade the years I spent there for my bachelor's degree for anything in the world. It was a time of unique community, where we students taught each other tools and techniques, organized courses and excursions, put on exhibitions, and even staged entire plays and productions. What an empowering experience of self-efficacy!

gear.description: My trusty Canon 70D accompanied me through my inexperienced student years. I must have taken 10,000 pictures with it, and 9,999 of them were blurry. Sadly, it spent its life below its potential, but it was always a loyal and well loved partner. (And yes, it's quite a weighty companion)

Teaser-Image.title: Sehetz Sarah Heitz Gear Canon 70 D.svg

list.Title: Als Gott Schlief
list.description: My bachelor's thesis – so much has happened around this project. There's the documentary film «Endlich Tacheles» and the video game «Als Gott Schlief»: Both deal with the family history of Yaar, a young Israeli who experiences third-generation trauma and seeks creative ways to cope. I created concept art for the video game, and that's why I appear as a protagonist in the film myself.
list.content_01_text: At the center was the idea of telling a Jewish family story set in Krakow in the 1930s through atmosphere, pacing, and interaction rather than explanation. Everyday life in the Kazimierz district is the entry point, while an underlying sense of threat slowly looms in the narrative. The project dealt with memory, transgenerational trauma, and the difficulty of positioning oneself as part of a later generation shaped by events it did not experience directly.
list.content_03_text: The project yielded material for two interconnected results: the documentary film «Endlich Tacheles,» which reflects on identity, heritage, and strained family relationships across generations, and, in parallel, the historical game concept for the video game «Als Gott Schlief» I was involved only in the beginning: an interdisciplinary process encompassing film, game design, and collaboration with animators, musicians, and writers.

team.description: Please excuse the image quality. It’s emotionally true. In 2018, I was working on my bachelor’s thesis, creating concept art for «Als Gott Schlief», a video game project by Yaar. At the same time, a Berlin-based studio was filming the documentary «Endlich Tacheles» about him, his family, their history, and how a video game might me an outlet for coping with it. Because of how closely I was involved with the project, I became part of the film. Designing characters and scenes for a game about memory and inherited trauma while the documentary showed the people carrying it.

gear.description: The comfort of a pencil lead on paper, the beautiful accidental effects that occur when the pigment rubs off onto the canvas, the smell of paint. All of that is simply put: my comfort zone. Things get exciting when you combine media: modeling clay, watercolors, pencil drawings? Why not!

Teaser-Image.title: Sehetz Sarah Heitz Gear Pen & Paper.svg

list.Title: BFS Rosling
list.description: Based on the vision of Superdot, I created a multi dimensional version of the iconic Hans Rosling diagram using Blender scripting, just months before AI assisted workflows became the standard. Under Nicole Lachenmeier’s art direction, it became an animated model for video, augmented reality, and print.
list.content_01_text: Below, you can explore the 3D model. Where does Switzerland stand in relation to China? Move through the dataset of 2020 and navigate the diagram in three dimensions. The visualization is multi dimensional. Income sits on the X axis, life expectancy on the Y axis, and CO₂ emissions per capita on the Z axis. Sphere size represents population. The larger the sphere, the larger the population. Color mark continents. Navigate the data yourself and explore the relationships between nations. For panning use the right click, or two fingers.
list.content_03_text: The production process was a particular technical challenge. While I had prior experience animating in Blender, its scripting interface was unfamiliar territory. I coded the diagram not only for visual effects in film production, but I also prepared it as a flexible asset adaptable for augmented reality environments and for print applications including posters and editorial brochures. Phew!
list.content_05_text: The materials shown here are excerpts from the printed brochure, which highlights three years: 1950, 1990, and 2020. The temporal comparison reveals a marked shift in global CO₂ emissions. It also illustrates China’s dramatic rise in income between 1990 and 2020, while many European nations converge into a relatively tight economic cluster, reflecting a different trajectory of development.

team.description: It is hard to overstate how important my time at Superdot has been for me. Fresh out of a bachelor’s program in a small German province, I found myself working in a studio where the art director had still studied typography directly under Weingart. What started as a traineeship grew into the most formative learning experience of my early career. Darjan and Nicole shaped my development and supported my strengths, for which I remain deeply grateful.

gear.description: Ahhh, Blender. I love you and your community, the many tutorials, the helpful users who will still be answering questions in forums even in 2025. I love that you're improving the industry standard and constantly working on yourself. You're the best tool, and I'm grateful you exist.

list.Title: SDGraphical
list.description: How do countries compare in achieving the Sustainable Development Goals? SDGraphical in its two editions was a team effort at Superdot: Nicole designed the layout, Darjan envisioned the graphs, Aaron coded the visualizations, and I collaborated with Nicole on icons and implementation.
list.content_03_text: The publication exists in two editions. The first, released in 2021 in Bern, introduced a new visual approach to communicating the Sustainable Development Goals, drawing on Otto Neurath’s Isotype. In 2024, we updated the publication with current datasets and expanded the system through an installation and an interactive microsite at the UN World Data Forum in Medellín, Colombia. Want to know more? Superdot shares some more insights, see the cases below.
list.content_05_text: Each of the 17 Goals follows the same structure. The opening spread introduces the Goal and a pre-selected indicator. An indicator represents one aspect of the overall Goal; some indicators describe it more clearly than others. A histogram-style overview then shows the global distribution and gives a quick sense of whether most countries meet, approach, or exceed the target. The next double spread compares two countries directly and details the percentage achieved. A line marks the continental average and places each country in relation to its region.

team.description: It is hard to overstate how important my time at Superdot has been for me. Fresh out of a bachelor’s program in a small German province, I found myself working in a studio where the art director had still studied typography directly under Weingart. What started as a traineeship grew into the most formative learning experience of my early career. Darjan and Nicole shaped my development and supported my strengths, for which I remain deeply grateful.

gear.description: After Effects, Bridge, Illustrator, InDesign, Lightroom, Photoshop, Premiere – that's my Adobe ABC. We designers need you, but we don't love you. For years, there was far too little innovation in these programs (thanks for the color search in InDesign, tho; the rest is peanuts), but I'm grateful for a tool that reliably lets me complete all my creative tasks.

list.Title: Web Illustrations
list.description: A website can't just stand on its own; it needs to be filled with life. For this page, I developed a short series showcasing my favorite tools in action.
list.content_01_text: In these illustrations, tools refuse to remain abstract. Cameras become too large to handle, software turns into something you have to carry, and digital devices suddenly take up physical space. The figures interact with their equipment in mildly impractical ways. Nothing appears efficient but everything is familiar.
list.content_03_text: Tools often feel less like solutions and more like long-term relationships. Some are supportive, others quietly demanding, most exist somewhere in between. Together, they form an inventory of objects that make work possible while constantly interfering with it.

list.content_05_text: Each illustration passes through three sketching phases: a rough draft, a refined line drawing, and a final vector version created in Affinity Designer 2 on iPad. The finished images rely on flat colors, clear outlines, and a deliberately limited palette. No textures, no depth, no drama.

list.Title: Flavor Packaging
list.description: Taste has color, form, and history. I developed the cartridge packaging for Carnault. Illustration, layout, and design combine to create the packaging for the four flavors. Each has a unique color palette with gradations to represent the individual nuances of the different tastes. The packaging invites you to dream—a world of pleasure and nostalgia.
list.content_01_text: The flying camel—a mythical creature and an explicit request from the Carnault team—flies over the horizon and whisks you away to one of four flavor worlds. Light-footed and free, quite unlike a familiar dromedary from another well-known brand.
list.content_03_text: The cartridge packaging is the first product I've designed that's actually on a store shelf. I had few constraints, was free to design it as I pleased, and coordinated the printing with the supplier. It was a very instructive process, and there's still room for improvement.
list.content_05_text: Due to other urgent tasks in Carnault's daily routine, I varied the color scheme of the illustration for the 4 flavors instead of creating entirely new illustrations.

team.description: Three brothers, one cigarette, and the entire Black Forest. Carnault is an electronic cigarette, developed and largely manufactured in Switzerland. It's a shared dream that we've continually expanded, refreshed, revitalized, and fueled over the past years. I joined the crew in 2021, when the ship had already been sailing for a good 10 years, just in time for the first working prototypes. Whether it's webshops, physical stores, or the design for the products surrounding the cigarette, in a startup, diverse collaboration and a strong team are essential!

gear.description: Who wouldn't love having their favorite tool always at hand? I grew up with digital drawing, from my first Wacom Bamboo Fun tablet at age eleven to over two Wacom Cintiqs (12 UX, 24 pro) that I lugged across Europe in my hand luggage several times. The iPad? For me, a lifelong dream.

Teaser-Image.title: Sehetz Sarah Heitz Gear Ipad Crop.svg
